channel.title: LTT Discussion - Local Transport Today
channel.copyright: Copyright: LTT Discussion - Local Transport Today

item.title: Will autonomous vehicles change our experiences of streets for better, or worse?
item.description: Evaluating autonomous vehicles in terms of their ability to help produce sustainable and healthy environments is important for understanding the potential impacts of this technology.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Obi Thompson Sargoni)

item.title: The need to cut transport emissions – and the role of shared transport in doing that
item.description: We accept that taxpayer subsidy should go into public transport. We should also accept that if we want shared transport to serve areas that are not commercially viable – but do not give it any subsidy – then it will not serve those areas.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Richard Dilks)

item.title: Better engagement for better streets
item.description: If we’re so sure that our proposals are for the benefit of the majority, why are we often only able to convince a minority? Assuming we believe the prize is worth fighting for, isn’t it worth finding new tactics?
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (John Dales)

item.title: Achieving change in a hostile environment
item.description: As Covid-19 accelerates calls for more safe city space for people, civic leaders face a challenge.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Mark Ames)

item.title: Beauty is only skin-deep. We should look under the surface of walking facilities
item.description: Here’s a theory: it’s an awful lot less contentious and disruptive to install attractive public realm than to take measures to elevate walking’s level of service.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Tom Cohen)

item.title: Our guide to better consultation is informed by some bruising encounters!
item.description: All too often, I’ve seen schemes lost or watered down because most politicians won’t or can’t tough it out.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Simon Munk)

item.title: London should be at the cutting edge of micromobility. So why is it lagging behind?
item.description: London risks missing out through poor co-ordination and a lack of vision across its multiple councils and transport authorities. Could the capital raise its game, and maybe even set a gold standard?
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Rob Whitehead)

item.title: Time to get back to normal and kick-start business as usual?
item.description: The line on a graph called ‘business as usual’ has simply become meaningless. Yes, we plead, let us feel we can lead normal lives, but for planning and forecasting we cannot credibly translate that into a tenable description of normality.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Phil Goodwin)

item.title: Battery electric buses will be key in our zero emission future
item.description: As local authorities and transport providers look to move away from fossil fuels, it is clear that there have never been more options on the market for low-carbon, environmentally friendly buses.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Steven Meersman)

item.title: Let’s embrace the benefits we can get from e-scooters
item.description: One of the upsides of the Covid-19 upheavals is that some things that have spent years circling around at normal transport policy and planning speed suddenly find themselves catapulted out into reality.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Richard Dilks)

item.title: A transport plan is needed for life after lockdown in rural areas
item.description: The benefits that people in rural areas have been experiencing have been as startling as in cities.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Alistair Kirkbride)

item.title: The wisdom of crowding: is there a new paradigm for collective transport?
item.description: The message that our health might be endangered unless we keep far more distant from other humans than we used to is likely to be one of the most lasting legacies of the present crisis. It’ll almost certainly be the most challenging for transport practitioners.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (John Dales)

item.title: Transport appraisal and planning in a time of imperatives
item.description: All discussion of strategic and local transport planning at present is seen through the lens of the urgent imperatives of the pandemic, which have changed the boundaries of policy in contradictory directions.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Phil Goodwin)

item.title: Covid-19 will change every piece of our transport system forever
item.description: Covid-19 will dramatically change our lives and, be under no illusion, the provision of all forms of transport. In the space of one week, public transport went from a good thing to use to being a good thing not to use.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Roger Davies)

item.title: Social inclusion on wheels
item.description: Too much emphasis in transport service and infrastructure planning goes on getting it right from the start; too little on adapting to lessons learned, feedback and changing needs.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Richard Dilks)

item.title: We’ve pressed pause on the capital’s transport system now let’s reset it
item.description: With social distancing looking set to continue for some time, people who are able to work at home will probably be the last people allowed to come back onto public transport.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Emma Gibson)

item.title: We can’t let the virus put commuters into cars – safe mass transit is the answer
item.description: The challenge for us all is to ensure that Joe Public doesn’t see the car as the only way to travel safely in the future.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Sam Ryan)

item.title: Planning for walking? Whatever will they think of next?
item.description: Authorities, agencies and professions whose role it should be to make walking easy, safe and pleasurable, have very rarely treated walking as a mode of transport worthy of its own guidance.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (John Dales)

item.title: Life after Covid-19
item.description: What behaviours can we retain from the radical changes we are experiencing? This is surely something Government should dwell on.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Richard Dilks)

item.title: When is an emergency not an emergency?
item.description: There’s no point declaring an emergency about anything unless you take some form of action in response.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (John Dales)

item.title: Re-think of side road junction layouts needed to ensure priority for pedestrians
item.description: The way we design our side roads has a huge impact on the lives (and deaths) of people walking, and is probably the most important aspect of highways design to get right.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Lucy Marstrand)

item.title: Driving change: travel in the 21st century
item.description: Some of the worst mistakes in transport investment have been supported by huge volumes of forecasts, surveys and studies, confidently published with little recognition of their inconsistencies and errors.
item.author: ed.ltt@landor.co.uk (Phil Goodwin)
